abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though the institutional development
            impact is only modest. Among the general lessons, it is
            conveyed that the use of Independent Panel of Experts
            (IPOEs) is effective, provided both the implementing
            agencies (IAs), and the IPOEs clearly understand the
            intended terms of reference, and the IAs adequately manage
            the panel's outputs. This reinforces, that in order to
            ensure cost-effectiveness, and maximize the benefit of
            technical assistance (TA), a proactive management of the
            consultants' assignment by the contracting project
            agency, must be enforced. Furthermore, payment terms of TA
            contracts should be linked, as possible, to measurable
            contract outputs, rather than relying on time-based
            payments, to reduce potential cost overruns, and/or delayed
            outputs. As well, international competitive bidding
            procedures are highly advantageous, when undertaking civil
            works in difficult physical situations, such as riverbank
            protection, particularly when contract management operates
            in an independent professional manner, unconstrained by
            outside interests. Specific lessons address the need to
            strengthen the procurement management capacity of the
            Bangladesh Water Development Board (BWDB), to avoid
            fragmentation of works, by developing a core of
            professionals within the implementing agency to supervise
            procurement matters, including as well, built-in periodic
            procurement audits for future designs. BWDB financial
            management should in addition, be strengthened through
            institutional arrangements to build capacity, assessed in
            the context of BWDB's institutional reform program.

abstracts.cdata!:
The River Bank Protection Project's
            principal objective is to prevent the erosion of riparian
            land at two locations on the west bank of the Brahmaputra by
            the construction and maintenance of improved river-bank
            protection works which will: 1) protect Sirajganj
            town's built-up and semi-urban areas from major damage
            and cumulative destruction; and 2) prevent the merger of the
            Brahmaputra and Bangali Rivers in the vicinity of Sariakandi
            and consequential increased regional flooding. A further
            objective is to assist the Government of Bangladesh (GOB) in
            developing permanent institutions for improved water sector
            planning, preserving the institutional capacity developed
            under the Flood Action Plan (FAP) and making
            multi-disciplinary planning part of Bangladesh's normal
            water sector planning processes. The project's
            components are: 1) rehabilitation and construction of
            river-bank protection works at two sites on the Brahmaputra
            River's west bank; 2) land acquisition and a program of
            resettlement for people displaced by project works; 3)
            technical assistance for implementation supervision and
            maintenance of works constructed under the project; 4)
            establishment and initial funding of a specialized
            operations and maintenance (O&M) Unit in the Bangladesh
            Water Development Board (BWDB) to maintain the riverbank
            protection works constructed under the project, and
            procurement of vehicles and equipment for the O&M Unit;
            5) institution building technical assistance to Water
            Resources Planning Organization (WARPO) to integrate the FAP
            within the framework of national water planning, produce a
            national water management plan and a portfolio of investment
            projects for the medium and long-term, and upgrade
            integrated water sector planning capability; and 6)
            institutional capacity building technical assistance to BWDB
            to improve the operation of the new regional accounting
            centers, and provision of equipment and transport to improve
            project supervision capability in the field and internal communications.

abstracts.cdata!:
This report presents the Environmental
            Impact Assessment (EIA) of the works arising from the River
            Training studies of the Bramhaputra River (BRTS), part of
            the Flood Action Plan, in respect of the immediate concerns
            of ensuring the security of certain parts of the Bramhaputra
            River Embankment (BRE) and major concentrations of
            infrastructural investment along the right bank of the
            river. The structural works associated with the first phase
            of this program of bank stabilization are known as the
            Priority Works. The EIA has been undertaken to ascertain
            what are the likely, significant environmental changes as a
            result of the implementation of the Priority Works and, if
            these changes are negative, what mitigating measures should
            be taken to lessen their impact both during construction and
            thereafter. These package of measures is sometimes referred
            to as an Environmental Management Plan (EMP).
